text: How does the author identify himself in the opening of this personal letter?
verseText: The elder to the beloved Gaius, whom I love in truth.

text: Who is the specific individual addressed in this letter?
verseText: The elder to the beloved Gaius, whom I love in truth.

text: What specific actions of Gaius does the author commend, based on reports from other brothers?
options: His faithfulness in walking in the truth and showing hospitality to traveling Christians
verseText: For I rejoiced greatly when the brothers came and testified to your truth, as indeed you are walking in the truth. Beloved, it is a faithful thing you do in all your efforts for these brothers, strangers as they are, who testified to your love before the church.

text: What experience brings the author the greatest joy?
options: Hearing that his children are walking in the truth
verseText: I have no greater joy than to hear that my children are walking in the truth.

text: The author mentions writing to the church but encountering opposition from whom?
verseText: I have written something to the church, but Diotrephes, who likes to put himself first, does not acknowledge our authority.

text: What was Diotrephes' primary motivation, according to the author?
verseText: ...Diotrephes, who likes to put himself first, does not acknowledge our authority.

text: Besides rejecting the author's authority and speaking against him, what other harmful actions did Diotrephes take?
options: He sent financial aid to the wrong people
He refused to welcome traveling brothers and excommunicated those who did
verseText: So if I come, I will bring up what he is doing, talking wicked nonsense against us. And not content with that, he refuses to welcome the brothers, and also stops those who want to and puts them out of the church.

text: What direct instruction does the author give Gaius regarding the imitation of behavior?
options: Do not imitate evil, but imitate good
verseText: Beloved, do not imitate evil but imitate good. Whoever does good is from God; whoever does evil has not seen God.

text: According to the author, what is the spiritual state of one who does good versus one who does evil?
options: The one doing good is from God; the one doing evil has not seen God
Both are equally loved by God
verseText: Whoever does good is from God; whoever does evil has not seen God.

text: In contrast to Diotrephes, who does the author commend as having a universally good testimony?
verseText: Demetrius has received a good testimony from everyone, and from the truth itself. We also add our testimony, and you know that our testimony is true.

text: Similar to the conclusion of 2 John, how does the author prefer to communicate rather than writing?
options: By hoping to see the recipient soon and speak face to face
By waiting for the recipient to visit
verseText: I had much to write to you, but I would rather not write with pen and ink. I hope to see you soon, and we will talk face to face.

text: What blessing does the author offer Gaius before the final greetings?
Who sends greetings to Gaius at the end of the letter?
verseText: The friends greet you. Greet the friends, every one by name.

text: What specific type of Christian workers was Gaius supporting, whom Diotrephes rejected?
options: Traveling missionaries working 'for the sake of the Name'
verseText: Beloved, it is a faithful thing you do in all your efforts for these brothers, strangers as they are... who went out for the sake of the Name, accepting nothing from the Gentiles. Therefore we ought to support people like these...

text: Why was it important for believers like Gaius to support these traveling workers?
options: So they wouldn't have to get secular jobs
So that believers may be fellow workers for the truth
verseText: Therefore we ought to support people like these, that we may be fellow workers for the truth.

text: What does the author pray for Gaius at the beginning of the letter?
options: That he may prosper in all things and be in health, as it goes well with his soul
That he would write a letter back
verseText: Beloved, I pray that all may go well with you and that you may be in good health, as it goes well with your soul.
